Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Testing the network hypothesis of Cellular Aging in Saccharomyces Cerevisiae

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit. What is aging? This question remains elusive despite over 150 years of research. In this project, the novel hypothesis is proposed that cellular aging is an emergent property of gene/protein networks. This hypothesis argues that the plasticity of cellular aging, 70~80% of natural variation in life span, is attributed mainly to the stochasticity of detrimental changes that can propagate through the networks. Polymorphic variations can alter stochastic processes of aging by influencing the strength and dynamics of interactions in the networks and can contribute to 20~30% of natural variation in life span. This hypothesis predicts that the rate of cellular aging is proportional to the robustness of the network, a prediction that will be tested in this project both computationally and experimentally. The first aim is to examine the statistical associations of the effects of genes on aging and their effects in robustness and to predict new genes associated with aging. The second aim is to test experimentally the link between network robustness and the rate of cellular aging. Several proxies of network robustness will be measured in a collection of wild isolates of yeast. The associations between these proxies of robustness and the rate of cellular aging will then be evaluated. By recognizing cellular aging as an emergent property, this novel network model of aging can provide a mechanistic foundation for other theories of aging. Because cellular aging is a system-level property, it cannot be pinpointed to specific genes. This explains the paradox in the field that not gene with a direct functional link to aging has yet to be found, even though over 80 genes are known to influence the aging process in yeast alone. The general principle of emergent properties of gene/protein networks will also offer new insights into the relationship between the genotype and phenotype of an organism.

Broader impacts. The project will benefits to the institutional research and teaching programs at an historically black women's college. This project will largely be carried out by undergraduate students from a minority background. By engaging these students in hypothesis-driven research and intense interdisciplinary training, it will cultivate a love of research and encourage their pursuits of science-related careers. This project will also invigorate the research program and enhance the research capacity at this college.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on a network hypothesis of aging: Cellular aging is an emergent property of gene networks. One direct prediction of this hypothesis is that aging is related to the network robustness, and this prediction has been addressed by both computational analysis and experimental tests in the model organism of the budding yeast. Computational analyses showed that growth rates, gene expression plasticity, and morphological plasticity are significantly associated with yeast lifespan. Experimental tests showed that lifespans in different yeast strains are significantly associated with their tolerances to hydrogen peroxide induced genomic instability. Hydrogen peroxide is a known source for oxidative stress. Cells’ abilities to maintain genome integrity in the presence of hydrogen peroxide represent the overall robustness of the cells. Moreover, we have developed a mathematical framework that can be used to evaluate network changes from experimental lifespan data. 


This project has directly trained over 30 African American female undergraduates, resulted in 1 peer-reviewed publication, 2 honor theses, 1 student presentations at an international conference, and 9 student presentations at national meetings. At least six of these students are pursuing PhDs in STEM. Components of this project were incorporated into three courses: BIO233 Microbiology, BIO386 Genomics, Proteomics, and Bioinformatics, and CIS115 Introduction to Programming. Moreover, many tutorial and training videos have been generated at our YouTube educational channel, http://www.youtube.com/qinstat.
